message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of axillary lymphadenopathy indicates the spread of cancer, which is a sign of poor prognosis. Although increased age is a risk factor for breast cancer and HER-2/neu positive is associated with a worse prognosis, axillary lymphadenopathy is a stronger predictor of poor prognosis. ER positive status is associated with a better prognosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of axillary lymphadenopathy suggests that the cancer has spread, increasing the likelihood of metastasis and a poor prognosis. While increased age may impact prognosis, it is not as significant as the presence of lymphadenopathy. ER and HER-2/neu status are important factors in determining treatment, but do not necessarily indicate poor prognosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of axillary lymphadenopathy suggests that the cancer has spread beyond the breast, which is a poor prognostic factor. Age, ER positivity, and HER-2/neu positivity can also affect prognosis, but axillary lymphadenopathy is the most important indicator of poor prognosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The histologic examination shows ER/PR and HER-2/neu positivity, suggesting a diagnosis of invasive breast cancer. Axillary lymphadenopathy is the most important indicator of a poor prognosis, as it suggests that the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes, which can increase the risk of metastasis. Age, ER positivity, and HER-2/neu positivity can also affect prognosis, but are not as strong of indicators as lymph node involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation suggests breast cancer, and the significant findings from the biopsy indicate a positive ER/PR and HER-2/neu status. Axillary lymphadenopathy is the most important indicator of a poor prognosis, as it indicates that the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes and possibly beyond. Increased age, while a risk factor, is not as strong an indicator as lymphadenopathy. ER positivity is actually a good prognostic factor, as it indicates that the cancer is hormone sensitive and can be treated with hormone therapy. HER-2/neu positivity can also be associated with a poor prognosis, but it is not as strong an indicator as lymphadenopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest breast cancer, and the palpable mass, lymphadenopathy, and mammography findings support this. The histologic examination and immunohistochemistry reveal that the tumor is ER/PR positive and HER-2/neu positive. However, among the options, axillary lymphadenopathy is the most important indicator of a poor prognosis, as it suggests that the cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes. Age, ER positivity, and HER-2/neu positivity may also impact prognosis, but axillary lymphadenopathy is the most significant factor.

ER positivity is a good prognostic indicator, while HER-2/neu positivity can vary depending on treatment options. Age is a factor to consider but is not the most important indicator in this case.

The other options are not necessarily indicative of a poor prognosis on their own. ER/PR positivity is actually a good prognostic factor as these cancers respond well to hormonal treatments. Age is a risk factor, but not the most important indicator of poor prognosis in this case.
